Nikolai, part of the answer to your question is in how NEAT activates netwo=
rks in general.  The type of network activation in NEAT is described in the=
 NEAT Users FAQ at 

http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html  

Under the=
 question:

How are networks with arbitrary topologies activated? 

The gen=
eral answer is that NEAT can evolve any arbitrary recurrent topology.  The =
important concept to understand is that activation travels the length of on=
e connection very tick of the clock.  So if there is a recurrent connection=
, it will travel over that connection just as it would a feedforward connec=
tion.  It will take as many ticks as there are links in the chain to make i=
t all the way through a particular recurrent loop or feedforward chain (or =
combination of the two).  

Another way to explain it is to point out that =
the activation process is simple:  It just sends activation from the output=
 of all current active nodes to the inputs of all nodes to which they conne=
ct in one time step.  There are no special rules for exit conditions or rul=
es for how many times something may propagate.  As long as you keep activat=
ing the network, activation will continue to propagate, similarly to our ow=
n brains.  (That is, our brains never "stop" until the end of life.)

Pleas=
e let me know if you need further clarification.

ken

 , which recurrent architecture is implemented in NEAT? Is it an Elman netw=

in a loop, what is the loop exit condition, etc... ?
